    Exercises 3

    Your Name Here

    12/7/2017

    Overview

    Here is a link to the text of these exercises.

    Question 1

    The Encode project has performed eCLIP experiments to map RNA binding protein (RBP) binding sites for > 100 RBPs. Go to the Encode website, search for eCLIP experiments, select an RBP eClip experiment, and load a BED file (bed narrowPeak file format) with the binding sites into R using just the url.

    Use the read_narrowPeak() function from valr to read in your bed file using just the URL. Do not download the file locally.

    Also, make sure that the file was generated using the hg19 genome build, and that you do not select the eCLIP mock input samples, which are negative controls. Display the bed tibble that you pulled from the Encode database and give a one to two sentence summary about the known functions of the RBP.

    Here’s an example. An eClip experiment for PTPB1 was performed (info here. I selected hg19 and in the file details menu and selected a bed narrowPeak file here. I copied the URL by right-clicking on Download ENCFF471GJ and selecting copy link address. Note that the extension of the file in the URL that you use should be .bed.gz, do not use bigBed, fastq, bam, or bigWig files.

    library(valr)
url <- "https://www.encodeproject.org/files/ENCFF471GJE/@@download/ENCFF471GJE.bed.gz"

read_narrowpeak(url)
    ## # A tibble: 229,446 x 10
##    chrom     start       end              name score strand   signal
##    <chr>     <int>     <int>             <chr> <int>  <chr>    <dbl>
##  1  chr7  98479380  98479408 PTBP1_HepG2_rep01  1000      + 4.114247
##  2  chr7  94298932  94298976 PTBP1_HepG2_rep01  1000      + 3.698511

    Interpretation

    Question 2

    Use bed_intersect() and some dplyr functions to determine how many eCLIP peaks are found in genes and how many are intergenic. (see the documentation on the invert argument for bed_intersect()). Use the hg19_genes.bed.gz bed file as your gene bed file (location shown below). Explain in the interpretation whether or not the RBP primarily binds to known (geneic) or unannotated (intergeneic) regions.

    genes <- system.file("extdata", "hg19_genes.bed.gz", package = "eda")
read_bed(genes, n_fields = 6)

    Strategy

    Interpretation

    Question 3

    Determine which gene has the largest number of binding sites for your RBP.

    Strategy

    Interpretation

    Question 4

    Use another function from valr (overview and documentation here to study a relationship between your eClip binding sites and genes in the gene bed file. Explain your question and answer. Some valr functions require a genome file, which indicates the lengths of the chromosomes.You can access this file as shown below.

    genome_file <- system.file("extdata", "hg19_genome.txt.gz", package = "eda")
genome <- read_genome(genome_file)

genome
